title: Rise in airline passengers, record EV sales, & more

news.title: More...
news.description:
+India's monthly domestic air passenger traffic rose 15% to around 1.29 cr passengers in Dec 2022.
+Retail sales of vehicles in India grew by 15.28% to 2.1 cr units in 2022: FADA.
+Delhi recorded the highest-ever monthly electric vehicle sales as compared to all other states and UTs. 7,046 EVs were sold in Delhi, a growth of 86%. 2 wheelers contribute around 55% of the total sales.
+Bengaluru-Chennai Expressway will be ready by March next year: Union Minister Nitin Gadkari. It is expected to reduce total travel time to 2 hours (5-6 hours currently).
+ISRO and Microsoft will collaborate to support the growth of space tech startups in India.

news.title: Word of the Day
news.description:
Net Debt
Net debt is the amount that is left after deducting a company’s cash (liquid assets) from its borrowings.
Net debt = borrowings - cash. 
It is used to determine whether the company will be able to pay its borrowings in case the lenders ask for repayment immediately.
The lesser the net debt, the better the ability.

news.title: 6 Day Course
news.description:
Investment made in ELSS funds can be used to give tax benefits in the current financial year only — even though they’re locked-in for 3 years.
This means, every new financial year, you need to make fresh investments in an ELSS fund to avail tax benefit under section 80C.
Any extra amount invested in one year does not carry over benefits to the next year.
Only investments made in a financial year can be used for benefits in the same financial year.
Do note, ELSS mutual funds’ lock-in of 3 years is the shortest lock-in period among all tax-savings investments.
Other options like tax savings FD, NPS, etc have much longer lock-in periods.
It goes without saying, ELSS mutual funds’ returns aren’t fixed or guaranteed. So far, they’ve given the highest returns (over the long term) among all tax-savings investment options.

news.title: Featured Question
news.description:
"What are Index Funds and how it differs from normal funds ?"
 
Mutual funds are active funds — meaning, the decision to buy, sell, or hold stocks is made by a fund manager and his/her team.
They research and choose stocks based on their investment philosophy.
The decision-making is active in nature.
Index funds on the other hand are passive. No person makes a buy or sell decision.
Index funds merely replicate an index.
For example, the index Nifty 50 is made up of the 50 biggest companies in India.
So a Nifty 50 index fund invests its money in the 50 biggest stocks in India maintaining weightage.
It also maintains the same weightage as the companies’ size.
So, Reliance is the biggest company in India - the index fund will buy more shares of Reliance, then next, the 2nd biggest company, and so on.
